p:
A recurring theme in discussions with podcast guests has been the link between social justice and environmental justice (Table 1). Guests consistently described how they have experienced environmental injustices in their personal and professional lives as it relates to their social identities such as race, gender identity, sexual orientation, disabilities, and so on. For example, a podcast guest Isaias Hernandez (Mulki 2020, episode 11), an environmental educator who runs the Instagram account “QueerBrownVegan,” talked about how he grew up in a poor community in southern California that was exposed to air pollution due to proximity to a toxic industrial plant. However, he did not realize his unjust community context until he was much older when he went to school and learned about environmental justice.Table 1
